commit_message:
Filter for local nodes in check_resource function

While having extra customizations inside a TripleO deployed
Pacemaker environment, say you have instance HA with
pacemaker_remoted or you need to configure an external arbitrator
for something, then the status of the resources for remote nodes
is "Stopped".
This leads to failures while, for example, scaling up.
This fixes the way status is checked, filtering just local nodes.

Co-Authored-By: Giulio Fidente <gfidente@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I8dc25f5d7031c265858afd5a266fda5315ae37a0
(cherry picked from commit 05b2a200ca2adc5b34bc1460d350f25f1fc18bbe)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/25/301825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nodes_local=$(pcs status | grep ^Online | sed 's/.*\[ \(.*\) \]/\1/g' | sed 's/ /\|/g') node_states=$(pcs status --full | grep "$service" | grep -v Clone | { egrep "$nodes_local" || true; } )

If cinder manages hundred of volumes, the cinder
volume service is taking a long time to start up.
Most of time is spent in:

The host_vols is only needed if there are updates

commit_message:
Remove object to dictionary translation logic

If cinder manages hundred of volumes, the cinder
volume service is taking a long time to start up.

Most of time is spent at object to dictionary
conversion in list_of_dicts_to_dict().

  dict(d, index=d[key])

We should remove this logic to avoid performance
degradation, and then use simple iteration for
referring volume object same as snapshot.

Also snapshot_update() in _sync_provider_info()
would be better to use 'update' instead of 'updt'.

Change-Id: Idde635b9c488e40e53377e0f3b48c8478df97a84
Closes-Bug: #1582505

commit_message:
[network] Configure DNS resolution

Configure DNS resolution for instances.

Closes-Bug: #1541192
backport: mitaka
Co-Authored-By: Matt Kassawara <mkassawara@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I7e536291bb0966969b3153481c734f71cb3cad5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/15/315415/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================================= Configure basic DNS resolution ======================================= The Background ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Dnsmasq can rely on DNS resolvers defined in host's resolv.conf, and it did by default. This may have introduced DNS timeouts if the DNS servers are not reachable for whatever reason. If you didn't want a DNS server, and you insert a default, then you could be leaking information about your network to a third-party. This page serves as a guide for how to configure DNS resolution for instances. The instructions covers a several ways to configure DNS resolvers: * To enable DNS resolution for instances on all neutron networks using the same one or more DNS resolvers. * To enable DNS resolution for instances on all neutron networks using DNS resolvers on the host running the DHCP agent. * To enable DNS resolution for instances on on individual networks using option --dns-nameserver with the neutron subnet-create command Default value of ``dnsmasq_local_resolv`` is configured to ``False``. DNS resolution for instances on all neutron networks ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Using the same one or more DNS resolvers ---------------------------------------- Configure ``dnsmasq_dns_servers`` option with comma-separated list of DNS servers which will be used by dnsmasq. #. Edit the ``[DEFAULT]`` section of the ``/etc/neutron/dhcp_agent.ini`` .. code-block:: console dnsmasq_dns_servers = 8.8.8.8,8.8.4.4 Using DNS resolvers on the host's resolv.conf --------------------------------------------- Edit the ``dhcp_agent.ini`` file and enable the ``dnsmasq_local_resolv`` option, dnsmasq then runs with the ``--no-resolv`` argument and instances are using DNS resolvers on the host in ``/etc/resolv.conf`` running the DHCP agent. Use with caution as this method can potentially leak internal DNS records. 1. Edit the nameserver in ``/etc/resolv.conf`` .. code-block:: console nameserver 8.8.4.4 2. Edit the ``[DEFAULT]`` section of the ``/etc/neutron/dhcp_agent.ini`` .. code-block:: console dnsmasq_local_resolv = True DNS resolution for instances on individual networks ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Using DNS resolvers set during neutron subnet-create command ------------------------------------------------------------ Use the ``--dns-nameserver`` option with the neutron subnet-create command to enable DNS resolution for instances on individual networks. .. code-block:: console $ neutron subnet-create demo-net TENANT_NETWORK_CIDR --name demo-subnet \ --dns-nameserver DNS_RESOLVER --gateway TENANT_NETWORK_GATEWAY

commit_message:
FIX the translation for overview page

"OpenStack Services" and "Servers" in overview cannot be translated
properly, because these words are defined in the localsettings
which are the global variables and these variables are changed
directly.
So there is a possibility that this values can be changed when
two or more users access to the Horizon GUI.
This patch creates the deep copy for changing the values in the
localsettings, and can avoid the affect from the other user
operations.

Change-Id: I2cca00a57f5a13902cc868563597ae5d971c0fff
Closes-Bug: #1580389
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-ui refs/changes/23/314823/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Implement Neutron:Port protection plugin

Change-Id: I1f72179b0d5936167d8ffea4c6ddd57b8bdc1087
Closes-Bug: #1560365
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/karbor refs/changes/75/296975/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_serialization import jsonutils from smaug.common import constants from smaug.common.constants import ProtectionStatus from smaug.services.protection.protection_plugins.network.neutron_plugin \ import NeutronPlugin # from smaug.services.protection.protection_plugins.network \ # import neutron_subnet_plugin_schemas as plugin_schemas LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class NeutronPortPlugin(NeutronPlugin): def __init__(self, context): super(NeutronPortPlugin, self).__init__() self._saved_data_key = 'port' def get_supported_resources_types(self): return constants.NEUTRON_PORT_RESOURCE_TYPE def get_options_schema(self, resource_type): # return plugin_schemas.OPTIONS_SCHEMA # TODO(chenhuayi) pass def get_restore_schema(self, resource_type): # return plugin_schemas.RESTORE_SCHEMA # TODO(chenhuayi) pass def get_saved_info_schema(self, resource_type): # return plugin_schemas.SAVED_INFO_SCHEMA # TODO(chenhuayi) pass def get_saved_info(self, metadata_store, resource): # TODO(chenhuayi) pass def create_backup(self, **kwargs): port_id = kwargs.get("port_id") checkpoint = kwargs.get("checkpoint") port = self.get_neutron_resource(kwargs.get("context"), port_id, 'show_port') bank = checkpoint.get_resource_back_section(port_id) bank.create_object(self._saved_data_key, jsonutils.dumps(port)) bank.create_object(self._state_key, ProtectionStatus.AVAILABLE) def restore_backup(self, **kwargs): # TODO(chenhuayi) pass def delete_backup(self, **kwargs): port_id = kwargs.get("port_id") checkpoint = kwargs.get("checkpoint") bank = checkpoint.get_resource_back_section(port_id) bank.delete_object(self._saved_data_key) bank.update_object(self._state_key, ProtectionStatus.DELETED)

commit_message:
WIP Searchlight Search Panel

This panel provides faceted search using the
OpenStack Searchlight service.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/searchlight/
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Searchlight

This patch is an in tree copy of the searchlight-ui plugin.

https://github.com/openstack/searchlight-ui/

If you are a deployer wanting to use searchlight,
please use the plugin.

SEE BLUEPRINT for information on installing searchlight service.

Change-Id: I0f5e2c9c83ff21b62589b7ab1b11fed2e0a9140e
Co-Author: Steve McLellan <steven.j.mclellan@gmail.com>
Co-Author: Rajat Vig<rajatv@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Author: Matt Borland <matt.borland@hpe.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint searchlight-search-panel
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/36/227036/36 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: /** * Copyright 2015, Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. * * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. * You may obtain a copy of the License at * * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 * * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and * limitations under the License. */ (function () { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.project.search') .service('horizon.dashboard.project.search.searchlightQueryUtils', SearchlightQueryUtils); SearchlightQueryUtils.$inject = []; /** * @ngdoc service * @name horizon.dashboard.project.search.resourceLocator * @description Locates resources in openstack dashboard. */ function SearchlightQueryUtils() { var service = { addSearchKeyword: addSearchKeyword, addBestGuessBoolQueryParam: addBestGuessBoolQueryParam, addDefinedBoolParam: addDefinedBoolParam, addDefinedQueryParam: addDefinedQueryParam, addQueryString: addQueryString, getTimeRangeBoolOption: getTimeRangeBoolOption, initializeBoolQuery: initializeBoolQuery }; return service; ////////////////// function initializeBoolQuery(query) { query = query || {}; query.bool = query.bool || {}; } function getTimeRangeBoolOption(boolType, field, from) { var range = {}; range[field] = {'from': from}; var option = {}; option[boolType] = {'range': range}; return angular.toJson({'bool': option}); } function addSearchKeyword(searchlightQuery, facetName, facetValue) { if (angular.equals('_type', facetName)) { searchlightQuery.type = searchlightQuery.type || []; searchlightQuery.type.push(facetValue); return true; } else if (angular.equals('_sort', facetName)) { searchlightQuery.sort = query.sort || []; searchlightQuery.sort.push(facetValue); return true; } else if (angular.equals('_offset', facetName)) { searchlightQuery.offset = facetValue; return true; } else if (angular.equals('_source', facetName)) { searchlightQuery._source = facetValue; return true; } else if (angular.equals('_limit', facetName)) { searchlightQuery.limit = facetValue; return true; } else { return false; } } function addDefinedQueryParam(query, facetValue) { if (facetValue.bool) { addDefinedBoolParam(query, facetValue.bool); } } function addDefinedBoolParam(query, bool) { initializeBoolQuery(query); if (bool.must) { query.bool.must = query.bool.must || []; query.bool.must.push(bool.must); } if (bool.should) { query.bool.should = query.bool.should || []; query.bool.should.push(bool.should); } if (bool.must_not) { query.bool.must_not = query.bool.must_not || []; query.bool.must_not.push(bool.must_not); } if (bool.minimum_should_match) { query.bool.minimum_should_match = bool.minimum_should_match; } } function addQueryString(query, inputQueryString) { if (angular.isDefined(inputQueryString)) { initializeBoolQuery(query); query.bool.must = query.bool.must || []; var queryString = {query_string: {query: inputQueryString}}; query.bool.must.push(queryString); } } function addBestGuessBoolQueryParam(query, param, field, value) { initializeBoolQuery(query); query.bool.must = query.bool.must || []; var newMust = {}; if (~value.indexOf('~') || field == 'name') { //TODO handle nested var queryString = { fuzzy_prefix_length: 2, fields: [field], query: (~value.indexOf('~')) ? value : value + '~' }; newMust.query_string = queryString; } else if (~value.indexOf('*')) { newMust.wildcard = param; } else { newMust.term = param; } if (~field.indexOf('.')) { var nestedMust = { 'nested': { 'path': field.split('.')[0], 'query': newMust } }; query.bool.must.push(nestedMust); } else { query.bool.must.push(newMust); } } } }());

commit_message:
Removing unused verbose variable

No references to the variable exist within the role
so it does not need to be defined in defaults/main.yml

Change-Id: Ie7c71bebb181d12c9bf989d1cbee22e61061accc

commit_message:
Rename container profile

This patch rename docker profile to 'container.dockerinc.docker' to
better reflect the namespace.

Change-Id: I366c808f5a357a1c5199c8e76662ef9de9061d26

commit_message:
Get rid of oslo-incubator requirement

For now, there is only a method heat.common.crypt:oslo_decrypt_v1 depends
on the heat/openstack/common/crypto/utils.py module, and the method is
unused, so we can remove the method and remove the whole oslo-incubator
requirement.

Change-Id: I0a3dad0de5e11d1c13cc5513372c55aaf6534dfc

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """oslo.i18n integration module. See http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/usage.html """ try: import oslo_i18n # NOTE(dhellmann): This reference to o-s-l-o will be replaced by the # application name when this module is synced into the separate # repository. It is OK to have more than one translation function # using the same domain, since there will still only be one message # catalog. _translators = oslo_i18n.TranslatorFactory(domain='heat') # The primary translation function using the well-known name "_" _ = _translators.primary # Translators for log levels. # # The abbreviated names are meant to reflect the usual use of a short # name like '_'. The "L" is for "log" and the other letter comes from # the level. _LI = _translators.log_info _LW = _translators.log_warning _LE = _translators.log_error _LC = _translators.log_critical except ImportError: # NOTE(dims): Support for cases where a project wants to use # code from oslo-incubator, but is not ready to be internationalized # (like tempest) _ = _LI = _LW = _LE = _LC = lambda x: x

subject: Service driver support in L2gw for south bound
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-02 02:57:53.000000000', 'files': ['networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/agent_api.py', 'networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/rpc_l2gw.py', 'etc/l2gw_plugin.ini', 'networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/plugin.py', 'networking_l2gw/tests/unit/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/test_agent_api.py', 'networking_l2gw/tests/unit/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/__init__.py', 'networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/__init__.py', 'networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/ovsdb/data.py', 'networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/common/constants.py', 'networking_l2gw/tests/unit/services/l2gateway/test_agent_scheduler.py', 'networking_l2gw/tests/unit/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/test_rpc_l2gw.py', 'networking_l2gw/tests/unit/services/l2gateway/ovsdb/test_data.py', 'networking_l2gw/services/l2gateway/agent_scheduler.py', 'networking_l2gw/tests/unit/services/l2gateway/test_plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-l2gw/commit/8fec2529e87554d846e36b4e98c08f71baeecab3', 'message': 'Service driver support in L2gw for south bound

The patch set provides a framework to support
service drivers so that the south bound implementation
need not be tied to only the L2gw agent communicating
over the RabbitMQ message bus. This will help to support
other types of south bound implementations like OpenDaylight.

Change-Id: I403c7c0f110d4ad95d803640508b78c1539d181f
Closes-Bug: 1478812

commit_message:
Service driver support in L2gw for south bound

The patch set provides a framework to support
service drivers so that the south bound implementation
need not be tied to only the L2gw agent communicating
over the RabbitMQ message bus. This will help to support
other types of south bound implementations like OpenDaylight.

Change-Id: I403c7c0f110d4ad95d803640508b78c1539d181f
Closes-Bug: 1478812
Author: Maruti  <maruti.kamat@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Manjunath Patil <mpatil@hp.com>
(cherry picked from commit 6dc23d5f3f4c663a2db05c437feed71595a16b18)

commit_message:
Revert "Add Rally plugin for Senlin tempest"

This reverts commit d9df44a0bb42f011c65ab7596f776495764f4fb8.

We won't use rally tempest plugin to evaluate senlin and all rally plugins for senlin will be contributed to rally repo.

Change-Id: Ifdac7a3498f71598cae8cdbd725269335157513c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/65/307565/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: This is the directory to hold Rally test jobs for Senlin benchmarking. To run a single rally test job, use the following cmd: $rally task start tempest_cluster_create_delete.yaml Note: Before Rally supports to install tempest plugin for specified deployment, manual installation of Senlin tempest plugin in Rally's tempest virtual environment is necessary for benchmarking Senlin with existing tempest test cases.

[i18n] Fix common.pot generation

Change-Id: I24ce22bf167b043ae1c3752ee3a0f8fca0b02144
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/29/319029/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Do not generate common from the whole common directory. # common.pot is generated by install guide build process. DIRECTORY=${DIRECTORY}/../install-guide sphinx-build -j $NUMBER_OF_CORES -b gettext $TAG ${DIRECTORY}/source/ \ ${DIRECTORY}/source/locale/ mv -f ${DIRECTORY}/source/locale/common.pot \ ${TOPDIR}common/source/locale/common.pot
deleted_lines: # common is imported from various RST documents, but what files are # used varies across RST documents. Thus we need an index file to include # all files under common. To this aim, we create such document called # 'common-work' dynamically to generate the POT file of common. # Do not generate common-rst from the whole common-rst directory. # common-rst.pot is generated by install guide build process. #DIRECTORY="doc/common-work" #TOPDIR="doc/" #mkdir -p $DIRECTORY/source #cp doc/common/source/conf.py $DIRECTORY/source/conf.py #ln -sf ../../common $DIRECTORY/source/common #cat <<EOF > $DIRECTORY/source/index.rst #.. toctree:: # :maxdepth: 2 # :glob: # # common/* #EOFif [[ "$REPOSITORY" = "openstack-manuals" && "$DOCNAME" = "install-guide" ]] ; then # save common.pot as common to translate mv -f ${DIRECTORY}/source/locale/common.pot \ ${TOPDIR}common/source/locale/common.pot fi

commit_message:
Adopt the openstackdocstheme

To get the specs pages to have the same look and feel as
manila's developer documentation and
the rest of the openstack documentation, we need to import
and render this theme.

This gives users a consistent experience as they may
be acquainted with the rest of the OpenStack documentation
(Developer Reference, Admin Guide, User Guide, API Guide etc.)
before perusing Manila Specs.

It also provides our specs the "log-a-bug" feature so
readers may bring any mis-information to our attention.

Change-Id: I3598bf5a75e7d3d40e877e6a7e8dda985345ab4e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-specs refs/changes/27/319027/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import openstackdocstheme html_theme_path = [openstackdocstheme.get_html_theme_path()] html_theme = 'openstackdocstheme'# A few variables have to be set for the log-a-bug feature. # giturl: The location of conf.py on Git. Must be set manually. # gitsha: The SHA checksum of the bug description. Automatically extracted # from git log. # bug_tag: Tag for categorizing the bug. Must be set manually. # These variables are passed to the logabug code via html_context. giturl = u'http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/manila/tree/doc/source' git_cmd = "/usr/bin/git log | head -n1 | cut -f2 -d' '" gitsha = os.popen(git_cmd).read().strip('\n') bug_tag = u'docs' # source tree pwd = os.getcwd() html_context = { "pwd": pwd, "gitsha": gitsha, "bug_tag": bug_tag, "giturl": giturl, "bug_project": "manila", }

revisions:

We move the prepare-node script to openstack-repos to prepare for the

element-deps at this point).  All places that are running the
node-devstack element are also already running the openstack-repos
element, so no changes need to be made yet.  When node-devstack is
removed, refrences to it will need to be changed to cache-devstack as it

Signed-off-by: Matthew Thode <mthode@mthode.org>

commit_message:
Move prepare-node to openstack-repos

We move the prepare-node script to openstack-repos to prepare for the
removal of node-devstack (which only exists as a collection of
element-deps at this point).  All places that are running the
node-devstack element are also already running the openstack-repos
element, so no changes need to be made yet.  When node-devstack is
removed, refrences to it will need to be changed to cache-devstack as it
is the only additional thing node-devstack depends on that is not
included in openstack-repos.

Change-Id: Iac1d100cafa803fc52eb908e9c1007803abb1e66
Signed-off-by: Matthew Thode <mthode@mthode.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/90/318990/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add Storage section in user guide

Describe how to use Cinder block with COE's

This section covers both ephemeral and persistent storage for
containers.  It describes how Cinder block is used by Kubernetes,
Swarm, Mesos, and how Magnum is providing support along with
the options for users to manage the storage.  Examples are
included.

The doc container-volume-integration.rst is updated to the
current status and incorporated into the user guide.

Partially implements: blueprint user-guide
Change-Id: Iecd1a58e7bc04dda905e4c43d709f9eec7f68b97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/92/317592/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: =============================================== Using Container Volume Integration Feature =============================================== For Magnum user, we use Container Volume Integration in Kubernetes, Swarm and Mesos. This document details instructions how to use the container volume integration in Kubernetes, Swarm and Mesos. Using container volume integration in Kubernetes ------------------------------------------------ **NOTE:** The Container Volume Model of Kubernetes needs the kubernetes version >= 1.1.1 and docker version >= 1.8.3 1. Store the Fedora Atomic micro-OS in glance The steps for updating Fedora Atomic images are a bit detailed.Fortunately one of the core developers has made Atomic images available at https://fedorapeople.org/groups/magnum:: cd ~ wget https://fedorapeople.org/groups/magnum/fedora-23-atomic-7.qcow2 glance image-create --name fedora-23-atomic-7 \ --visibility public \ --disk-format qcow2 \ --os-distro fedora-atomic \ --container-format bare < fedora-23-atomic-7.qcow2 2. Edit the file:: sudo vi /opt/stack/magnum/magnum/templates/kubernetes/kubecluster.yaml The default value of the kube_version entries needs to change 'v1.0.6' to 'v1.1.8', then restart magnum-conduct service.(Magnum team will make the step automation as soon as possible.) 3. Create the baymodel. The new attribute volume-driver for a baymodel specifies the volume backend driver to use when deploying a bay. The volume-driver value needs to be specified as 'cinder' for kubernetes:: magnum baymodel-create --name k8sbaymodel \ --image-id fedora-23-atomic-7 \ --keypair-id testkey \ --external-network-id public \ --dns-nameserver 8.8.8.8 \ --flavor-id m1.small \ --docker-volume-size 5 \ --network-driver flannel \ --coe kubernetes \ --volume-driver cinder 4. Create the bay:: magnum bay-create --name k8sbay --baymodel k8sbaymodel --node-count 1 To enable the container volume integration in kubernetes, log into each minion node of your bay and perform the following step 5, step 6, step 7 and step 8: 5. Configure kubelet:: sudo vi /etc/kubernetes/kubelet Comment out the line:: #KUBELET_ARGS=--config=/etc/kubernetes/manifests --cadvisor-port=4194 Uncomment the line:: #KUBELET_ARGS="--config=/etc/kubernetes/manifests --cadvisor-port=4194 --cloud-provider=openstack --cloud-config=/etc/kubernetes/kube_openstack_config" **NOTE:** This is a temporary workaround, and Magnum team is working on a long term solution to automate this step. 6. Enter OpenStack user credential:: sudo vi /etc/kubernetes/kube_openstack_config The username, tenant-name and region entries have been filled in with the Keystone values of the user who created the bay. Enter the password of this user on the entry for password:: password=ChangeMe 7. Restart Kubernetes services:: sudo systemctl restart kubelet 8. Run the docker container:: sudo docker run -v /usr/local/bin:/target jpetazzo/nsenter Kubernetes container volume integration has configured by the above steps, And you can use the kubernetes container volume now. The following steps is an example for container volume integration with kubernetes bay. 1. Create the cinder volume:: cinder create --display-name=test-repo 1 ID=$(cinder create --display-name=test-repo 1 | awk -F'|' '$2~/^[[:space:]]*id/ {print $3}') The command will generate the volume with a ID. The volume ID will be specified in Step 2. 2. Create a container in this bay. The following example illustrates how to mount an cinder volume for a pod. Create a file (e.g nginx-cinder.yaml) describing a pod:: cat > nginx-cinder.yaml << END apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: aws-web spec: containers: - name: web image: nginx ports: - name: web containerPort: 80 hostPort: 8081 protocol: TCP volumeMounts: - name: html-volume mountPath: "/usr/share/nginx/html" volumes: - name: html-volume cinder: # Enter the volume ID below volumeID: $ID fsType: ext4 END **NOTE:** The cinder volume ID needs to be configured into the yaml file so that an existing Cinder volume can be mounted in a pod by specifying the volume ID in the pod manifest as follows:: volumes: - name: html-volume cinder: volumeID: $ID fsType: ext4 3. Create a pod with container. Please refer to the quickstart guide on how to connect to Kubernetes running on the launched bay.:: kubectl create -f ./nginx-cinder.yaml You can log in the container to check if existing the mountPath, and check if your cinder volume status is 'in-use' by running the command 'cinder list'. Using container volume integration in Swarm ------------------------------------------- *To be filled in* Using container volume integration in Mesos ------------------------------------------- 1. Create the baymodel. One of the new attributes volume-driver for a baymodel specifies the volume backend driver to use when deploying a bay. The volume-driver value needs to be specified as rexray for Mesos. The other new attributes rexray_preempt for a baymodel is an optional parameter here which enables any host to take control of a volume irrespective of whether other hosts are using the volume. If this is set to false then mostly plugins ensure safety first for locking the volume:: magnum baymodel-create --name mesosbaymodel \ --image-id ubuntu-mesos \ --keypair-id testkey \ --external-network-id public \ --dns-nameserver 8.8.8.8 \ --master-flavor-id m1.magnum \ --docker-volume-size 4 \ --tls-disabled \ --flavor-id m1.magnum \ --coe mesos \ --volume-driver rexray \ --labels rexray-preempt=true 2. Create the mesos bay:: magnum bay-create --name mesosbay --baymodel mesosbaymodel --node-count 1 3. Create the cinder volume and a container in this bay:: cinder create --display-name=redisdata 1 Create the following mesos.json file:: cat > mesos.json << END { "id": "redis", "container": { "docker": { "image": "redis", "network": "BRIDGE", "portMappings": [ { "containerPort": 80, "hostPort": 0, "protocol": "tcp"} ], "parameters": [ { "key": "volume-driver", "value": "rexray" }, { "key": "volume", "value": "redisdata:/data" } ] } }, "cpus": 0.2, "mem": 32.0, "instances": 1 } END **NOTE:** When the mesos bay is created using this baymodel, the mesos bay will be configured so that an existing cinder volume can be mounted in a container by configuring the parameters to mount the cinder volume in the json file:: "parameters": [ { "key": "volume-driver", "value": "rexray" }, { "key": "volume", "value": "redisdata:/data" } ] 4. Using the REST API of Marathon:: MASTER_IP=$(magnum bay-show mesosbay | awk '/ api_address /{print $4}') curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ http://${MASTER_IP}:8080/v2/apps -d@mesos.json You can log in the container to check if existing the mountPath, and check if your cinder volume status is 'in-use' by running the command 'cinder list'.

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: I4f8b4742bd86bc29749c358e89a7583c2c7f063b
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

fullstack: test for east west traffic

Fullstack test to test east west traffic through
legacy router.

Partial-Bug: #1583028
Change-Id: I3bfdd6cfafd5d4d1aa6a310efc9c8a8cb817ac46

added_lines: import netaddrfrom neutron.agent.l3 import dvr_fip_ns from neutron.agent.l3 import dvr_snat_nsfrom neutron.agent.linux import interfacefrom neutron.common import constantsfrom neutron.tests.fullstack.resources import machine class TestL3Agent(base.BaseFullStackTestCase): @staticmethod def _get_namespace(id, ns_prefix=l3_agent.NS_PREFIX): ret_ns = namespaces.build_ns_name(ns_prefix, id) return ret_ns @staticmethod def _append_suffix(dev_name, test_namespace_suffix): # If dev_name = 'xyz123' and the suffix is 'hostB' then the result # will be 'xy_stB' return '%s_%s' % (dev_name[:-4], test_namespace_suffix[-3:]) def get_external_device_name(self, port_id, test_namespace_suffix): return self._append_suffix( (namespaces.EXTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX + port_id) [:interface.LinuxInterfaceDriver.DEV_NAME_LEN], test_namespace_suffix) @staticmethod def _assert_namespace_exists(ns_name, sleep=1): ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(ns_name) utils.wait_until_true(lambda: ip.netns.exists(ns_name), sleep=sleep) def _is_router_interface_up( self, router_id, device_owner=constants.DEVICE_OWNER_ROUTER_INTF): ports = self.client.list_ports( device_id=router_id, device_owner=device_owner)['ports'] if len(ports) and ports[0]['status'] == 'ACTIVE': return True return False def _block_until_router_interface_up( self, router_id, device_owner=constants.DEVICE_OWNER_ROUTER_INTF): utils.wait_until_true( functools.partial( self._is_router_interface_up, router_id, device_owner=device_owner), timeout=90, sleep=3) def _create_public_network(self, tenant_id): cidr = self.environment.configure_public_network() network = self.safe_client.create_network( tenant_id, name='public', public=True) self.external_gateway_ip = str(cidr[1]) # Reserve ip from x.x.x.2 to x.x.x.254 for l3 agent on public network self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, network['id'], str(cidr), gateway_ip=self.external_gateway_ip, enable_dhcp=False, allocation_pools=True, start=str(cidr[2]), end=str(cidr[254])) return network def block_until_fip_namespace_exists(self, host, external_network): test_namespace_suffix = host.l3_agent.get_namespace_suffix() namespace = "%s@%s" % ( self._get_namespace( external_network, ns_prefix=dvr_fip_ns.FIP_NS_PREFIX), test_namespace_suffix, ) self._assert_namespace_exists(namespace, sleep=3) def delete_gw_address(self, router, ns_prefix=l3_agent.NS_PREFIX): test_namespace_suffix = \ self.environment.hosts[0].l3_agent.get_namespace_suffix() namespace = "%s@%s" % ( self._get_namespace(router['id'], ns_prefix=ns_prefix), test_namespace_suffix, ) gw_port = self.client.list_ports( device_id=router['id'], device_owner='network:router_gateway')['ports'][0] port_name = self.get_external_device_name( gw_port['id'], test_namespace_suffix) gw_interface = ip_lib.IPWrapper(namespace=namespace).device(port_name) for fip in gw_port['fixed_ips']: if (netaddr.IPAddress(fip['ip_address']).version == constants.IP_VERSION_4): gw_address = fip['ip_address'] gw_interface.addr.delete(gw_address) gw_interface.addr.flush(constants.IP_VERSION_4) break class TestLegacyL3Agent(TestL3Agent): def test_snat(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() public = self._create_public_network(tenant_id) router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id, external_network=public['id']) private_net = self.safe_client.create_network(tenant_id) subnet = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, private_net['id'], '20.0.0.0/24', enable_dhcp=False) vm = self.useFixture( machine.FakeFullstackMachine( self.environment.hosts[0], private_net['id'], tenant_id, self.safe_client)) self.safe_client.add_router_interface(router['id'], subnet['id']) self._block_until_router_interface_up(router['id']) vm.block_until_ping(self.external_gateway_ip) self.delete_gw_address(router) vm.assert_no_ping(self.external_gateway_ip) def test_floatingip(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() public = self._create_public_network(tenant_id) router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id, external_network=public['id']) private_net = self.safe_client.create_network(tenant_id) subnet = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, private_net['id'], '20.0.0.0/24', enable_dhcp=False) vm = self.useFixture( machine.FakeFullstackMachine( self.environment.hosts[0], private_net['id'], tenant_id, self.safe_client)) self.safe_client.add_router_interface(router['id'], subnet['id']) self._block_until_router_interface_up(router['id']) vm.block_until_ping(self.external_gateway_ip) self.safe_client.create_floatingip( tenant_id, public['id'], vm.ip, vm.neutron_port['id']) vm.block_until_ping(self.external_gateway_ip) class TestHAL3Agent(TestL3Agent): class TestDVRL3Agent(TestL3Agent): def setUp(self): host_descriptions = [ environment.HostDescription( l3_agent=True, dvr_agent_mode='dvr_snat'), environment.HostDescription(l3_agent=True, dvr_agent_mode='dvr')] env = environment.Environment( environment.EnvironmentDescription( network_type='vxlan', l2_pop=True, dvr=True), host_descriptions) super(TestDVRL3Agent, self).setUp(env) def test_snat_and_floatingip(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() public = self._create_public_network(tenant_id) router = self.safe_client.create_router( tenant_id, dvr=True, external_network=public['id']) private_net = self.safe_client.create_network(tenant_id) subnet = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, private_net['id'], '20.0.0.0/24', enable_dhcp=False) vm = self.useFixture( machine.FakeFullstackMachine( self.environment.hosts[1], private_net['id'], tenant_id, self.safe_client)) vm.block_until_boot() self.safe_client.add_router_interface(router['id'], subnet['id']) self._block_until_router_interface_up( router['id'], device_owner=constants.DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_INTERFACE) # test centralized snat vm.block_until_ping(self.external_gateway_ip) # Remove gw address to test external connectivity with floatingip self.delete_gw_address(router, ns_prefix=dvr_snat_ns.SNAT_NS_PREFIX) vm.assert_no_ping(self.external_gateway_ip) # Create floatingip self.safe_client.create_floatingip( tenant_id, public['id'], vm.ip, vm.neutron_port['id']) self.block_until_fip_namespace_exists( self.environment.hosts[1], public['id']) # Test external connectivity with floatingip vm.block_until_ping(self.external_gateway_ip)

commit_message:
Allow for excepted operations in migrations

The TestModelsMigrations.test_branches test checks that no schema
elements are created in the contract branch and no schema elements are
dropped in the expand branch. But we have some exceptions and reasons
for those exceptions. Update the test to allow for this.

Change-Id: Ib0693f5ac04a1810b43b338ead3b2d6f2f34dad3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/33/317733/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collections creation_exceptions = collections.defaultdict(list) if not (isinstance(clauseelement, migration_help.CREATION_OPERATIONS) and hasattr(clauseelement, 'element')): return # Skip tables that were created by mistake in contract branch element = clauseelement.element element_name = element.name if isinstance(element, sqlalchemy.Index): element_name = element.table.name for sa_type_, excepted_names in creation_exceptions.items(): if isinstance(element, sa_type_): if element_name in excepted_names: self.fail("Migration from contract branch contains create command") # Due to some misunderstandings and some conscious decisions, there # are contract migrations which create elements. These excepted # elements must be returned by a method in the script itself. The # name of the method must be 'contract_creation_exceptions' and the # method must have a docstring (which should explain the reason for # the exception). Here we build a list of the excepted elements and # verify that they are documented. script = alembic_script.ScriptDirectory.from_config( self.alembic_config) for m in list(script.walk_revisions(base='base', head='heads')): if migration.CONTRACT_BRANCH not in (m.branch_labels or [None]): continue get_excepted_elements = getattr( m.module, 'contract_creation_exceptions', None) if not get_excepted_elements: continue explanation = getattr(get_excepted_elements, '__doc__', "") if len(explanation) < 1: self.fail("%s() requires docstring with explanation" % '.'.join([m.module.__name__, get_excepted_elements.__name__])) for sa_type, elements in get_excepted_elements().items(): creation_exceptions[sa_type].extend(elements)
deleted_lines: if isinstance(clauseelement, migration_help.CREATION_OPERATIONS): # Skip tables that were created by mistake in contract branch if hasattr(clauseelement, 'element'): element = clauseelement.element if any([ isinstance(element, sqlalchemy.Table) and element.name in ['ml2_geneve_allocations', 'ml2_geneve_endpoints'], isinstance(element, sqlalchemy.Index) and element.table.name == 'ml2_geneve_allocations' ]): self.fail("Migration from contract branch contains create " "command")

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: I685393349fbbd18a4a71205f20109437bdda0def

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: Ic6d94043570d2f55d42bdea5a1d493c96e75cbea
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_spec_helper refs/changes/21/318821/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added "Choosing a COE" to user guide

This patch adds the "Choosing a COE" section to the Magnum user guide.

Partially-implements blueprint user-guide
Change-Id: Ic121423a46973b5f5ba79e5b3308ac6ae1925b40
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/45/317745/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #. `Choosing a COE`_============== Choosing a COE ============== Magnum supports a variety of COE options, and allows more to be added over time as they gain popularity. As an operator, you may choose to support the full variety of options, or you may want to offer a subset of the available choices. Given multiple choices, your users can run one or more bays, and each may use a different COE. For example, I might have two bays that use Kubernetes, and one bay that uses Swarm. Choosing which COE to use depends on what tools you want to use to manage your containers once you start your app. If you want to use the Docker tools, you may want to use the Swarm bay type. Swarm will spread your containers across the various nodes in your bay automatically. It does not monitor the health of your containers, so it can't restart them for you if they stop. It will not automatically scale your app for you (as of Swarm version 1.2.2). You may view this as a plus. If you prefer to manage your application yourself, you might prefer swarm over the other COE options. Kubernetes is more sophisticated than Swarm 1.2.2. It offers an attractive YAML file description of a pod, which is a grouping of containers that run together as part of a distributed application. This file format allows you to model your application deployment using a declarative style. It has support for autoscaling and fault recovery, as well as features that allow for sophisticated software deployments, including canary deploys and blue/green deploys. Kubernetes is very popular, especially for web applications. Apache Mesos is a COE that has been around longer than Kubernetes or Swarm. It allows for a variety of different frameworks to be used along with it, including Marathon, Aurora, Chronos, Hadoop, and `a number of others. <http://mesos.apache.org/documentation/latest/frameworks/>`_ Finding the right COE for your workload is up to you, but Magnum offers you a choice to select among the prevailing leading options. Once you decide, see the next sections for examples of how to create a bay with your desired COE.
deleted_lines: #. `Choosing COE`_============ Choosing COE ============ *To be filled in* Buyer's guide with example use case, can use this as model: http://www.openstack.org/software/project-navigator

commit_message:
Update Image section in user guide

New details for building Fedora Atomic image

There is a new automated build process for the Fedora Atomic image
for Kubernetes and Swarm, based on diskimagebuilder.  Remove the
document for manual build since it is outdated, and update the
user guide accordingly, pointing to the new instruction using
diskimagebuilder.

Partially implements: blueprint user-guide
Change-Id: Ie8bc70989f7322a6184e2ab1cf9653ad79f92f24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/64/317764/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: ========================================= Building and updating Fedora Atomic image ========================================= For Magnum development, we use a Fedora Atomic image prebuilt with a certain version of Docker, Kubernetes, etcd and Flannel. This document details instructions for building the image update it to incorporate your own changes. The basic steps are: 1. Choose the packages and build a package repo. 2. Run a Docker container with Fedora 21 and build the rpm-ostree repo. 3. Create the new glance image from this Docker container. 4. Alternatively, update an existing container from this rpm-ostree repo. This document was tested with Fedora 21. This should also work for Fedora 22 or other version with minor adjustment, and the document will be updated when they are tested. Create the package repo ======================= Find the package version that you want from:: https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org/packages/<packagename> This URL does not contain a package name, so you will provide the package name in the URL. For our case, we will use the three packages named 'kubernetes', 'etcd', and 'flannel'. For example:: https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org/packages/kubernetes/0.20.0/0.3.git835eded.fc23/src/kubernetes-0.20.0-0.3.git835eded.fc23.src.rpm https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org/packages/etcd/2.0.13/2.fc23/src/etcd-2.0.13-2.fc23.src.rpm https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org/packages/flannel/0.5.0/1.fc23/src/flannel-0.5.0-1.fc23.src.rpm Next we build a package repo for these particular packages. We use an automated package builder from:: https://copr.fedoraproject.org/coprs If you don't have an account, you can create one on:: http://fedoraproject.org Once you log into Fedora copr via https://copr.fedoraproject.org, follow these steps: - Click on "Add a new project" and fill in the necessary information. - Check the box for fedora-21-x86_64. - In the box "Initial packages to build", refer the kojipkgs site mentioned above. Cut and paste the links for the desired src.rpm package. - Click build. The build may take some time depending on how busy the system is. When the build completes successfully, go to the Overview tab and look under the column for "Yum repo". Find the link for a repo file to point to your newly built package in copr. Save the text from this link to use later. Build and host rpm-ostree repo ============================== You will need a server with Docker installed. Download this build configuration:: git clone https://github.com/jasonbrooks/byo-atomic.git Make sure httpd is not running on your server since we need to map port 80 to apache that will run in the Docker instance. If port 80 is already in use, we will get an error when starting the Docker instance indicating that the address is already in use. Verify that port tcp/80 is vacant by running this command:: sudo netstat -antp | grep :80 The output should show no process on port 80. For example, if apache is using port 80, you would see something like:: tcp6 0 0 :::80 :::* LISTEN 26981/apache2 In the Dockerfile, we download the fedora 21 image and set up the environment. If you are running on Ubuntu, the Dockerfile does need a minor workaround for the httpd logs directory. Edit the Dockerfile and in the line with mkdir, insert a command for "mkdir /etc/httpd/logs" as follows:: mkdir /etc/httpd/logs && mkdir -p /srv/rpm-ostree/repo && cd /srv/rpm-ostree/ && ostree --repo=repo init --mode=archive-z2 Build a Docker container image to be used for hosting the rpm-ostree repo:: sudo docker build --rm -t $USER/atomicrepo byo-atomic/. where $USER is the user logged in. When the build completes, you can see the image by running:: sudo docker images Start a container using the new Docker image. This will start apache in the new container with tcp/80 mapped to the host:: sudo docker run --privileged -d -p 80:80 --name atomicrepo $USER/atomicrepo Then log into this Docker container:: sudo docker exec -it atomicrepo bash Once inside the Docker container, run the commands:: cd fedora-atomic git checkout f21 nscd Edit the file fedora-atomic-docker-host.json to add the repo pointing to the copr package repo. Update the line "repos" as follows:: "repos": ["fedora-21" , "my-copr-repo"], You can rename "my-copr-repo" as needed, but make sure to use the same name in the two steps following. From the link on the copr site above, save the content for the repo pointer in a file named "my-copr-repo.repo" in the same directory, then make the following changes in the file. Rename the first line as:: [my-copr-repo] And modify this flag:: gpgcheck=0 Then build the rpm-ostree:: rpm-ostree compose tree --repo=/srv/rpm-ostree/repo fedora-atomic-docker-host.json When this is completed, Apache should be running on the Docker container and serving the content of the new rpm-ostree repo. From outside the container, the repo can be accessed as:: http://<ip>/repo Create the new image ==================== From within the Docker container where the rpm-ostree repo has been built, install additional tools:: yum install -y rpm-ostree-toolbox nss-altfiles yum-plugin-protectbase Create a new glance image:: export LIBGUESTFS_BACKEND=direct rpm-ostree-toolbox create-vm-disk /srv/rpm-ostree/repo fedora-atomic-host fedora-atomic/f21/x86_64/docker-host my-new-f21-atomic.qcow2 The new image my-new-f21-atomic.qcow2 is in the current directory. Update an existing Fedora Atomic server ======================================= You may update an existing Fedora Atomic server to derive a new one. If you have a nova instance created from an existing Fedora Atomic glance image, you may update it from the rpm-ostree repo above. On this server, edit this file as root:: sudo vi /etc/ostree/remotes.d/fedora-atomic.conf Add the content (substitute the <ip> for your Docker instance):: [remote "fedora-atomic-host"] url=http://<ip>/repo branches=fedora-atomic/21/x86_64/docker-host; gpg-verify=false Run the command:: sudo rpm-ostree upgrade When the upgrade is completed, reboot to switch to the new version:: sudo systemctl reboot Once you have the modified server, you may snapshot it to create a new glance image from it, and use that new glance image for subsequent new Magnum bays. Note however that because of the way Atomic manages backup, this approach will bloat the image size.

commit_message:
Fix the swarm test for gate

The swarm bay occasionally closes the connection when creating a
container. The cause of this issue is unknown but we modified the
swarm test to make it more robust.

Closes-Bug: #1556675
Change-Id: I9c7c0361a5be4b56f7846a3fbc4a7683a3e2ede2

the expected value.

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: Ie2f5d288747a1045b1cf344e58f713d28ffcd787
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-murano refs/changes/09/318809/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: Ia9cf80c0b29e2c98d97fa5692cf3da353ddf538c
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime import yaml class HeatResource(object): def __init__(self, resource_id, type): self.resource_id = resource_id self._type = type self._properties = {} def set_property(self, key, value): self._properties[key] = value def toDict(self): resource_dict = { "type": self._type, "properties": self._properties } return resource_dict class HeatTemplate(object): heat_template_version = datetime.date(2015, 10, 15) description = "smaug checkpoint restore template" def __init__(self): self._resources = {} def put_resource(self, heat_resource): self._resources[heat_resource.resource_id] = heat_resource.toDict() def toDict(self): template_dict = { "heat_template_version": self.heat_template_version, "description": self.description, "resources": self._resources } return template_dict def dumpToYamlFile(self, file): with open(file, "w") as f: yaml.dump(self.toDict(), f)

commit_message:
Add bp:tempest-run-cmd

Proposes a spec for a domain-specific ``tempest run`` command.
This would create testrepository-based test runner with options
specific to the use of Tempest.

Co-Authored-By: Matthew Treinish <mtreinish@kortar.org>

Change-Id: I588c4a9b940937f9ad4f85138da58e551d10c2eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qa-specs refs/changes/34/269934/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. ================================== Tempest Run Command ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/tempest-run-cmd Describes a domain-specific ``tempest run`` command to be used as the primary entry point for running Tempest tests. Problem Description =================== There are a wide range of Tempest use cases ranging from OpenStack gate testing to the testing of existing public and private clouds across multiple environments and configurations. Each of these user scenarios has its own requirements and challenges. Currently, the Tempest test suite can be executed using any testr-compatable runner. While this allows for some flexibility, it does not provide a consistent experience for consumers of Tempest. In addition, because these test runners are in no way specific to Tempest any, items that are domain specific (such as configuration) must be performed out-of-band using shell scripts or other means. Since an effort is already underway to create a set of Tempest-specific command line tooling, this spec further defines a ``tempest run`` command. This spec addresses the following problems: - Providing a flexible runner that enables multiple approaches to the test discovery and execution processes - Facilitating ease of configuration and execution of Tempest across multiple environments and configurations - Builds on testrepository directly in order to leverage current and future testrepository capabilities Proposed Change =============== This spec's implementation can be broken down into three logical components: - A command line interface that users will interact with - A function that takes the command line arguments and decides which tests should be executed - A client that drives the execution of tests by interfacing directly with the testr internals in testrepository The logical flow of the proposed test runner is as follows: - Parse any command line arguments. - Set necessary environment variables for Tempest based on inputs. - Determine the set of tests to run based on the provided regexes and other filters. - Call into an existing testrepository entry point with the testr-specific arguments and the list of tests to be executed. - Receive the results from test execution. - Perform any post-processing on the test results, if applicable. Command Line Interface ---------------------- The list of proposed command line arguments are as follows: Test Execution:: --fail-fast --exec-mode <serial/parallel> --workers <workers> --list --list-pretty Example: +-tempest/ +-api/ +-compute/ | test_authorization.py | test_quotas.py +-image/ +-v1/ | test_image_members.py | test_images.py | test_images_negative.py +-v2/ | test_image_member.py | test_images.py | test_images_negative.py Test Selection and Discovery:: --test-dir <test directory> --package <test package> --tag <tag name> --include <regex or file name> --exclude <regex or file name> Sample regex file: (^tempest\.api) # Comments about this regex tempest.scenario.test_server_basic_ops # Matches this test explicitly Aliases for most commonly used regexes:: --gate --smoke Output:: --subunit --html <file name> Tempest Configuration:: --config <config file> --accounts <accounts file> Test Selection -------------- The proposed solution uses test discovery logic based on the implementation used by the os-testr project. The following workflow describes the proposed test discovery and selection process: 1. If either a test package or directory is passed as a parameter, then the runner will use that as the root directory for test discovery. Otherwise, the current directory is used. 2. All tests in the root directory are loaded into a list. 3. Any white list regexes are applied to the list of tests. 4. Any black list regexes are applied to the list of tests. 5. Any tags are applied to the remaining tests. 6. The remaining tests are returned for execution. Testrepository Integration -------------------------- One of the goals of this spec is to develop an entry point from Tempest that integrates directly with testrepository rather than calling out to testr via subprocess. This integration is a more robust design that allows new features in testrepository to propagate more easily to the Tempest runner. Inversely, as the Tempest runner evolves, features that would be useful to any test runner can be pushed down the stack into testrepository. The planned integration point of the tempest run command with testrepository is the `CLI UI for testr`_. However, this only one possible approach. The final solution is likely to evolve during development. .. _CLI UI for testr: https://github.com/testing-cabal/testrepository/blob/master/testrepository/commands/__init__.py#L165 Projects ======== * openstack/tempest Implementation ============== - Create a ``tempest run`` entry point in Tempest using cliff - Handle setup of Tempest specific options such as Tempest configuration - Implement test discovery and selection logic based on the provided filtering options (regexes, tags, etc.) - Create the client code that will interact with testrepository and control test execution and results gathering - Implement handlers for any non-subunit output formats Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: - dwalleck - sammyd - slowrie Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Mitaka-3 References ========== - `Mitaka Design Summit CLI Session`_ .. _Mitaka Design Summit CLI Session: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/mitaka-qa-tempest-run-cli Previous Implementations and Specs - `os-testr runner`_ - `Prototype by mtreinish`_ - `Previous Tempest CLI spec`_ .. _os-testr runner: https://github.com/openstack/os-testr/blob/master/os_testr/os_testr.py .. _Prototype by mtreinish: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/197378/8/tempest/cmd/run.py .. _Previous Tempest CLI spec: https://github.com/openstack/qa-specs/blob/master/specs/tempest/tempest-cli-improvements.rst

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

commit_message:
Improve ceilometer-api install documentation

Change-Id: Ida25e59033910cff155fc3eeb06d7af9391b4913
Closes-Bug: #1453845
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/51/310351/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. only:: obs or rdo or ubuntu Configure the Apache HTTP server -------------------------------- .. only:: rdo #. Edit the ``/etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf`` file and configure the ``ServerName`` option to reference the controller node: .. code-block:: apache ServerName controller #. Create the ``/etc/httpd/conf.d/wsgi-ceilometer.conf`` file with the following content: .. code-block:: apache Listen 8777 <VirtualHost *:8777> WSGIDaemonProcess ceilometer-api processes=2 threads=10 user=SOMEUSER display-name=%{GROUP} WSGIProcessGroup ceilometer-api WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/ceilometer/app WSGIApplicationGroup %{GLOBAL} <IfVersion >= 2.4> ErrorLogFormat "%{cu}t %M" </IfVersion> ErrorLog /var/log/httpd/ceilometer_error.log CustomLog /var/log/httpd/ceilometer_access.log combined </VirtualHost> .. only:: ubuntu #. Edit the ``/etc/apache2/apache2.conf`` file and configure the ``ServerName`` option to reference the controller node: .. code-block:: apache ServerName controller #. Create the ``/etc/apache2/sites-available/wsgi-ceilometer.conf`` file with the following content: .. code-block:: apache Listen 8777 <VirtualHost *:8777> WSGIDaemonProcess ceilometer-api processes=2 threads=10 user=SOMEUSER display-name=%{GROUP} WSGIProcessGroup ceilometer-api WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/ceilometer/app WSGIApplicationGroup %{GLOBAL} <IfVersion >= 2.4> ErrorLogFormat "%{cu}t %M" </IfVersion> ErrorLog /var/log/httpd/ceilometer_error.log CustomLog /var/log/httpd/ceilometer_access.log combined </VirtualHost> #. Enable the Identity service virtual hosts: .. code-block:: console # ln -s /etc/apache2/sites-available/wsgi-ceilometer.conf /etc/apache2/sites-enabled .. only:: obs #. Edit the ``/etc/sysconfig/apache2`` file and configure the ``APACHE_SERVERNAME`` option to reference the controller node: .. code-block:: apache APACHE_SERVERNAME="controller" #. Create the ``/etc/apache2/conf.d/wsgi-ceilometer.conf`` file with the following content: .. code-block:: apache Listen 8777 <VirtualHost *:8777> WSGIDaemonProcess ceilometer-api processes=2 threads=10 user=SOMEUSER display-name=%{GROUP} WSGIProcessGroup ceilometer-api WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/ceilometer/app WSGIApplicationGroup %{GLOBAL} <IfVersion >= 2.4> ErrorLogFormat "%{cu}t %M" </IfVersion> ErrorLog /var/log/httpd/ceilometer_error.log CustomLog /var/log/httpd/ceilometer_access.log combined </VirtualHost> .. only:: ubuntu or rdo or obs Finalize installation --------------------- .. only:: obs * Start the Telemetry services and configure them to start when the system boots: .. code-block:: console # systemctl enable openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service # systemctl start openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service .. only:: rdo * Start the Telemetry services and configure them to start when the system boots: .. code-block:: console # systemctl enable openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service # systemctl start openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service .. only:: ubuntu or debian * Restart the Telemetry services: .. code-block:: console # service ceilometer-agent-central restart # service ceilometer-agent-notification restart # service ceilometer-api restart # service ceilometer-collector restart
deleted_lines: Finalize installation --------------------- .. only:: obs * Start the Telemetry services and configure them to start when the system boots: .. code-block:: console # systemctl enable openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service # systemctl start openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-agent-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service .. only:: rdo * Start the Telemetry services and configure them to start when the system boots: .. code-block:: console # systemctl enable openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service # systemctl start openstack-ceilometer-api.service \ openstack-ceilometer-notification.service \ openstack-ceilometer-central.service \ openstack-ceilometer-collector.service .. only:: ubuntu or debian * Restart the Telemetry services: .. code-block:: console # service ceilometer-agent-central restart # service ceilometer-agent-notification restart # service ceilometer-api restart # service ceilometer-collector restart

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: I0c45d7a0ec49d3cb8e6b1881e28100d1b84e60e7
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move LVM tests to test_lvm_driver.py

test_volume.py covers too many things.

Also fixes a latent test bug caused by
assigning directly to utils.execute in
test_do_iscsi_discovery.

Change-Id: I9fae942f313a7523168c5bc890f09ad57795dff9

subject: Get the replica volume ref for DR
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-02 08:29:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/32d4a4e202d9671f27f79bd4a0ac3b0fea693bcf', 'message': "Get the replicated volume ref for DR

This function will be helpful in DR scenario for
production & disaster recovery sites which are two
independent OpenStack cloud. Cloud admin and DR manage
system cloud get the replicated volume ref after
creating replicating volumes in production site, and
then manage replicated volumes in DR site for failover
when disaster happens.

Changes:
1. Only allow admin to querying replication_driver_data &
replicaiton_extended_status. Those information should only
be know by admin users.

2. Return the 'replicatied_volume_ref' in response body of
querying volume.

Change-Id: Ieda66b6bc73b973112fb64ae24155580d7e6bbf5
Implements: buleprint: get-replicated-volume-ref-for-dr

then manage replicated volumes in DR site for failover

Changes:

be know by admin users.

2. Return the 'replicatied_volume_ref' in response body of
querying volume.

Change-Id: Ieda66b6bc73b973112fb64ae24155580d7e6bbf5
Implements: blueprint get-replicated-volume-ref-for-dr
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-12-07 01:18:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/bee5f3fffdda1bfb542407f5aeba75b3603ab839', 'message': "Get the replica volume ref for DR

This function will be helpful in DR scenario for
production & disaster recovery sites which are two
independent OpenStack cloud. Cloud admin and DR manage
system cloud get the replica volume ref after
creating replicated volumes in production site, and
then manage replica volumes in DR site for failover
when disaster happens.

Changes:
1. Only allow admin to querying replication_driver_data &
replicaiton_extended_status. Those information should only
be know by admin users.

2. Return the 'replica_volume_ref' in response body of

commit_message:
Get the replica volume ref for DR

This function will be helpful in DR scenario for
production & disaster recovery sites which are two
independent OpenStack cloud. Cloud admin and DR manage
system could get driver-specific reference to replica
volume after creating replicated volumes in production
site, and then manage replica volumes in DR site for
failover purpose when disaster happens.

Changes:
1. Only allow admin to query rep_target_id.
   This information should only be known by admin users.
2. improve some doc bugs in replication.

APIImpact
Change-Id: Ieda66b6bc73b973112fb64ae24155580d7e6bbf5
Implements: blueprint: get-replica-volume-ref-for-dr

commit_message:
Adding more information to storlet_handler info

In order to know if a certain functionality is
supported throught storlets, it is not enough
to know if the storlet_handler exists in the
pipeline (which is what currently covered by info)
but we also need the ability to know which storlets
are installed. Thus, we want to export the name
of the container holding the storlets.

It might be that gateways other then the current one
would store the storlets in a different manner, thus
we also export the class name of the gateway implementation

A usage of this is the spark use case, where we test
if the relevant storlet exists in order to decide whether
to activate the pushdown or not

This involves adding a new test and somewhat refactoring
the config parser.

Bonus: Fixing the ant deploy_host_engine and deploy_container_engine
that got broke with recent installation refactoring

Change-Id: I971244ef048ea4f580e95ac5be92b3768fd60929

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: I94a8697cb60bc7a84f5790e8bbe46aa9c05ad509
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Updates xiv_ds8k driver name

The xiv_ds8k driver now supports IBM XIV, Spectrum Acclerate,
FlashSystem A9000, FlashSystem A9000R and DS8000 storage systems.
Therefore it should be renamed to IBM Storage driver.

Change-Id: I8db502134abea59c19fc4549dd2bd20dbc22d0e2
backport: mitaka

commit_message:
Add network_update RPC into SR-IOV agent

SR-IOV agent doesn't listen for network_update notification, but it's
desired in QOS when network updated with a new QOS policy. This patch
adds it into this agent.

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/mech_sriov/agent/test_sriov_nic_agent.py

Change-Id: I06a7ca411da31bccabddec9c0adca6b8e6eab7cc
Closes-Bug: #1504166
(cherry picked from commit 7084fa8a17510a7a1a5221736fb3bd330b0ad86c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/53/285353/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collectionsimport six # 1.1 Support Security Group RPC (works with NoopFirewallDriver) # 1.2 Support DVR (Distributed Virtual Router) RPC (not supported) # 1.3 Added param devices_to_update to security_groups_provider_updated # (works with NoopFirewallDriver) # 1.4 Added support for network_update target = oslo_messaging.Target(version='1.4') def network_update(self, context, **kwargs): network_id = kwargs['network']['id'] LOG.debug("network_update message received for network " "%(network_id)s, with ports: %(ports)s", {'network_id': network_id, 'ports': self.agent.network_ports[network_id]}) for port_data in self.agent.network_ports[network_id]: self.agent.updated_devices.add(port_data['device']) self.network_ports = collections.defaultdict(list) [topics.NETWORK, topics.UPDATE], # we don't want to process updates for devices that don't exist device_info['updated'] = (updated_devices & curr_devices - device_info['removed']) def _update_network_ports(self, network_id, port_id, mac_pci_slot): self._clean_network_ports(mac_pci_slot) self.network_ports[network_id].append({ "port_id": port_id, "device": mac_pci_slot}) def _clean_network_ports(self, mac_pci_slot): for netid, ports_list in six.iteritems(self.network_ports): for port_data in ports_list: if mac_pci_slot == port_data['device']: ports_list.remove(port_data) if ports_list == []: self.network_ports.pop(netid) return port_data['port_id'] self._update_network_ports(device_details['network_id'], port_id, (device, profile.get('pci_slot'))) port_id = self._clean_network_ports(device) if port_id: 'profile': {'pci_slot': pci_slot}}
deleted_lines: # 1.1 Support Security Group RPC target = oslo_messaging.Target(version='1.1') self.mac_to_port_id_mapping = {} # we don't want to process updates for devices that don't exist device_info['updated'] = updated_devices & curr_devices self.mac_to_port_id_mapping[device] = port_id port_id = self.mac_to_port_id_mapping.get(mac) if port_id: profile = {'pci_slot': pci_slot} 'profile': profile} del self.mac_to_port_id_mapping[mac]

commit_message:
Mitigate restriction for fixed ips per dhcp port

When number of fixed ips per dhcp port exceeds max_fixed_ips_per_port,
a dhcp resync will be triggered.

The bug report stated how simply this issue can be triggered.
Moreover, "max_fixed_ips_per_port" value should be used for non-DHCP
port only and DHCP port is not affected by this parameter.

Conflicts:
	neutron/db/ipam_backend_mixin.py

Liberty changes:
- adopt similar 'trusted port' filter for opencontrail plugin;
- for contrail plugin, all exception types are transformed into contrail
  specific flavours, so modified a new test case to allow specifying a
  custom exception name to expect from an invalid request.

Change-Id: Iaa9ed6949383ba6a7ce0b3ffd9dcced663126317
Co-authored-by: NGUYEN TUONG THANH <thanhnt@vn.fujitsu.com>
Closes-Bug: #1179713
(cherry picked from commit 8f036fd34011bbf138815b21e2ef4c9760a5e0e6)

commit_message:
Manage existing volume with invalid host

A volume with invalid host is created when manage existing
volume with actions via Horizon dashboard, where it's entered
invalid host name. This patch fixes it, that is, it's not allow
to create a volume with invalid host.

Change-Id: Idd32f06c2f6c14813e21c83fde8671c41eb03653
Closes-Bug: #1580095

commit_message:
Add ebuilds directory for basic Gentoo support in nodepool

This patch adds basic Gentoo support so that we can start allowing
projects to support Gentoo through nodepool.

Change-Id: Ic3d6b01b9810768404236ec09d2121e9691d029d

commit_message:
Mock out poller in ovsdb unittests

The second thread running in ovsdb connection crashed due to not passing
file descriptor to poller. This patch mocks out the poller as it's not
used in the tests to avoid false tracebacks in the logs.

Change-Id: I62e87e3248d176e5db7fe57bfb4467176ba05392
Closes-Bug: 1583069

subject: disable_fallocate also disables fallocate_reserve
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-17 01:08:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/c7cb8533c6323cadfe7f9ddf3e8f8179483eed98', 'message': "Disable fallocate_reserve in SAIO object-servers

A SAIO tends to have smallish XFS partitions / loopback files and
since the Swift fallocate_reserve default has changed this causes
issues when running functional tests on a SAIO.

The reason being fallocate_reserve > 0, which is now 1%, causes
a block of Swift code[1] to check to see if placing an object will
cause the XFS filesystem to be below fallocate_reserve space free.
When the max_file_size defaults to 5G and the standard SAIO loopback
filesystem is 1G, this causes 507's to occur during functional tests.

SAIO object servers already sets 'disable_fallocate = true' which makes
the fallocate function call a noop, but this doesn't effect the above
mentioned block of code.

One option is to make disable_fallocate also effect this effect of
fallocate_reserve. That is, disable_fallocate also disables
fallocate_reserve. However, having the ability to disable the actual
fallocate, but still being able to have space free is a nice feature.

So this change simply adds `fallocate_reserve = 0` to the SAIO
object-server configs and as well as adds a 'Known Issues' section to
the SAIO developer documentation which includes a warning about
fallocate_resverve on SAIOs.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/utils.py#L617-626

Change-Id: I727bfb0861ea26fe2f16ad55f4d36ae088864d8f
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-17 04:04:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/c06171e136d4522addf51f3518e9f3656ed58325', 'message': "disable_fallocate also disables fallocate_reserve

Currently when disable_fallocate is true it disables calling the
fallocate syscall, but it doesn't disable fallocate_reserve. This
patch fixes this.

This problem has caused functional tests to fail in our SAIOs, since
SAIOs have disable_fallocate set but the fallocate_reserve space free
checking was still being run creating 507 responses. This is thanks
to the change in fallocate_reserve default changing from 0 to 1%.

Because fallocate_reserve and disable_fallocate causes SAIO functional
tests to fail a section called 'Known Issues' has been added to the
SAIO developer documentation which includes a warning about
using fallocate_reserve on SAIOs.

Change-Id: I727bfb0861ea26fe2f16ad55f4d36ae088864d8f

commit_message:
disable_fallocate also disables fallocate_reserve

Currently when disable_fallocate is true it disables calling the
fallocate syscall, but it doesn't disable fallocate_reserve. This
patch fixes this.

This problem has caused functional tests to fail in our SAIOs, since
SAIOs have disable_fallocate set but the fallocate_reserve space free
checking was still being run creating 507 responses. This is thanks
to the change in fallocate_reserve default changing from 0 to 1%.

Because fallocate_reserve and disable_fallocate causes SAIO functional
tests to fail a section called 'Known Issues' has been added to the
SAIO developer documentation which includes a warning about
using fallocate_reserve on SAIOs.

Change-Id: I727bfb0861ea26fe2f16ad55f4d36ae088864d8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/58/317158/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fallocate_reserve = 0

commit_message:
Fix probe failure and small things

This is follow up for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/283351/.

Probe fix:
- The probe in the patch now fails (sometimes success luckily)
  because inbound X-Timestamp is deprecated at the change,
  f581fccf71034818d19062593eeb52a4347bb174, so we can not use
  X-Timestamp to make an object with arbitrary timestamp anymore
  from outside of Swift. This patch makes the probe to use internal
  client to put the objects to make the inconsistent situation.

Small things:

- Enable expirer split brain test even if we have just one policy.
- FAIL rather than ERROR if the object was expired incorrectly
- ObjectBrainSplitter now uses the policy set at instance variable in
  default instead of random choice of ENABLED_POLICIES.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistair.coles@hpe.com>

Change-Id: I757dbb0f1906932ef5d508b48b4120f2794b3d07

commit_message:
Neutron: only do ARP_CMD if IP_BRD is not an empty string

Some third party CI systems leave PUBLIC_INTERFACE as the default,
but do not actually create the device. ip would set errno to 1 when
this happens[1], and that's fine - however arping would exit with errno
set to 2, which triggers the exit_trap and stops stacking.[2]

[1]: http://openstack.fit-tecnologia.org.br:10000/36/295836/6/check/hitachi-hnas-ssc/3362683/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2016-05-12_17_24_40_458

[2]: http://openstack.fit-tecnologia.org.br:10000/36/295836/6/check/hitachi-hnas-ssc/3362683/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2016-05-12_17_24_40_545

Change-Id: Iaf08b475eeec5e179a11a42d35fe532b2a15aa41

commit_message:
pin puppet-ceph to stable/hammer

We're now working on adding Jewel (new LTS in Ceph) support in
puppet-ceph, but our CI will start to gate on it from Newton cycle.
So let's pin puppet-ceph to stable/hammer so we make our stable CI more
stable.

Change-Id: I52943adae6a8feceb927a8f1eedcd0e890f4a198
